column6: One day the master was out, and then the lad, as curious as could be, hurried to the chamber where his master kept his wondrous apparatus for changing copper into silver, and where was his mirror in which he could see all that was passing in the world, and where was the shell which when held to the ear whispered all the words that were being spoken by any one the master desired to know about.
column7: Jednoho dne nebyl učitel doma a žák, zvědavostí celý bez sebe, běžel do pracovny, kde měl učitel svůj přístroj, co měnil měď ve stříbro, zrcadlo, které ukazovalo všechno dění na celém světě, a mušli, která, když se k uchu přiložila, šeptala všechno, co říkal ten, o kom se učitel chtěl něco dozvědět.

column6: Then Jan and his wife got down from the tree, took as many money-bags as they could carry on the door, and went straight home.
column7: Potom Jan a jeho žena slezli, vzali tolik pytlíků, kolik jen na dveřích mohli pobrat, a šli rovnou domů.

column6: And Jan bought his wife more cows, and more pigs, and they lived happy ever after.
column7: Jan koupil ženě další stračeny a další prasata a žili si šťastně až do smrti.

column6: “ One ’ s enough, I tell you. ”

column6: “ You are under me, so look sharp; clean the spit and the dripping-pan, make the fires, wind up the jack, and do all the scullery work nimbly, or - ” and she would shake the ladle at him.

column6: The more she begged and scolded, the more he shook his head; and when at last she lost patience and cried that the fairies would surely come and fetch him away, he only laughed and said he wished they would, for he would like one to play with.
column7: Čím víc prosila a zlobila se, tím víc vrtěl synek hlavou, že ne, a když jí nakonec všechna trpělivost došla a křikla na něj, že si ho tedy rarach dozajista přijde odnést, ještě se zasmál a odpověděl, že doufá, že tomu tak opravdu bude, protože zrovna s někým takovým by si chtěl hrát.

column6: He walked up and down with his purchase; but it was in vain he tried to play a tune, and instead of pocketing pence, the boys followed him hooting, laughing, and pelting.

column6: “ Well, come again, or not come again, ” said the woman, “ I ’ ll have one for supper. ”

column6: “ But you can ’ t, if they ain ’ t come, ” said the girl.
column7: " Nevemeš, dyš nedošly. "

column6: Soon after this, his master had a ship ready to sail; and as it was the custom that all his servants should have some chance for good fortune as well as himself, he called them all into the parlour and asked them what they would send out.
column7: Nedlouho nato chystal se Dickův pán loď na moře vypravit, a protože v kraji bylo zvykem, že když se vypravuje loď, má se také všem služebným umožnit k bohatství přijít, sezval je pán všechny k sobě do salonu a zeptal se, co oni sami chtějí lodí poslat do vzdálených krajin k prodeji.

column6: They all had something that they were willing to venture except poor Dick, who had neither money nor goods, and therefore could send nothing.
column7: Všichni měli něco, co mohli poslat a tím na štěstí vsadit, jen Dick neměl ani peníze, ani jiný majetek, a tak nemohl poslat nic.

column6: “ He ’ s taking a turn for the better at last! ” she said to herself; but he was thinking just then that, when next a fairy came to play with him, he might not get off quite so easily as he had done this time.
column7: " Tak se snad přeci jen polepší, " říkala si, a on zrovna přemýšlel o tom, že napříště, kdyby si s ním přišla hrát nějaká vílí malenka, nemusel by už vyváznout tak snadno jako předešlého večera.

column6: And away went the wife to the parlour chimney, and she pulled the rag with the ten pounds in it from the parlour chimney, and she gave the whole sum to the soldier, telling him that her old man was to use as much as he wanted, and to send back the rest.
column7: Do komína došla a šátek s deseti librami zlata stáhla dolů a celý ho vojákovi dala s tím, ať si její starý vezme, kolik bude potřebovat, a zbytek ať pošle zpátky.

column6: The king sent for Tom in great haste, but being fully aware of the danger of royal anger, he crept into an empty snail-shell, where he lay for a long time until he was almost starved with hunger; but at last he ventured to peep out, and seeing a fine large butterfly on the ground, near the place of his concealment, he got close to it and jumping astride on it, was carried up into the air.
column7: Král urychleně poslal pro Tomíka, ale ten, plně si vědom nebezpečenstva královského hněvu, zalezl do prázdné šnečí ulity a tam ležel tak dlouho, až hlady téměř zašel, ale nakonec se přece odvážil vykouknout, a vida velikého motýla, který seděl na zemi vedle Tomíkova úkrytu, vskočil na něj obkročmo a vznesli se do výšky.

column6: And many a tale she could tell of the “ good folk ” calling to each other in the oak-trees, and the twinkling lights hopping on to the very window-sill, on dark nights; but in spite of the loneliness, she lived on from year to year in the little house, perhaps because she was never asked to pay any rent for it.
column7: Vdova mohla mnohé vyprávět o skřítcích, co na sebe volávali ve větvoví dubů, nebo o blikavých světlech přiskočivších za tmavých nocí třeba až na samu okenici, ale i přesto, a přes tu velikou samotu, žila tam v domku rok za rokem, snad i proto, že za něj po ní nikdo nechtěl ani dukát.

column6: But she did not care to sit up late, when the fire burnt low, and no one knew what might be about; so, when they had had their supper she would make up a good fire and go off to bed, so that if anything terrible did happen, she could always hide her head under the bed-clothes.

column6: If she had been a good little old Woman, she would have waited till the Bears came home, and then, perhaps, they would have asked her to breakfast; for they were good Bears - a little rough or so, as the manner of Bears is, but for all that very good-natured and hospitable.
column7: Kdyby byla pořádnou hodnou stařenou, počkala by, než se medvědi vrátí, a oni by ji možná pozvali s nimi posnídat, protože to byli hodní medvědi - trošičku snad ráznější, jak už to u medvědů chodí, ale přesto moc přátelští a pohostinní.

column6: Now Dick had heard many, many very strange things about the great city called London; for the country people at that time thought that folks in London were all fine gentlemen and ladies; and that there was singing and music there all day long; and that the streets were all paved with gold.
